title: 113_s1268
content: The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, signed in 2010, is defined in this section. It also defines the Compact of Free Association between the two countries. Public Law 99-658 is amended to include the results of the Compact Review. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, signed in 2010, is approved with exceptions and conditions. If Palau withdraws over $5,000,000 from the trust fund in certain fiscal years, payments under the Agreement will be withheld until reimbursement is made. In fiscal years 2011, 2012, or 2013, payments under the Compact of Free Association to the Republic of Palau will be withheld if withdrawals from the trust fund exceed $5,000,000. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer necessary funds to the Secretary of the Interior for implementing certain provisions of the Agreement. Authorization is given for appropriations to subsidize postal services to Palau, the Marshall Islands, and Micronesia. The curr_chunk discusses appropriations for postal services to Palau, the Marshall Islands, and Micronesia, as well as funding for Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association. It also repeals a section of a previous Act. The curr_chunk discusses the Compact Section 211(f) Fund. The Government of the United States will contribute $30,250,000 to the Fund in accordance with a schedule spanning fiscal years 2014 to 2023. Additionally, a grant of $6,912,000 for fiscal year 2014 and $2,000,000 annually from 2015 to 2024 will be provided for the Infrastructure Maintenance Fund. The Republic of Palau will match contributions made by the United States. The Government of the Republic of Palau will match the contributions made by the United States by making quarterly contributions of $150,000 to the Infrastructure Maintenance Fund from fiscal year 2014 through fiscal year 2024. The Government of the Republic of Palau will match the contributions made by the United States with quarterly contributions of $150,000 to the Infrastructure Maintenance Fund from fiscal year 2014 through fiscal year 2024. Additionally, a Fiscal Consolidation Fund will be established. The Government of the United States will provide Palau with $10,000,000 in fiscal year 2014 to reduce government arrears. Economic assistance to Palau will amount to $69,250,000 over several fiscal years, starting from 2014. The Government of the United States will provide Palau with decreasing amounts of economic assistance over fiscal years 2015 to 2023, totaling $57,250,000. The funds will be distributed quarterly unless specified otherwise. Additionally, infrastructure projects will be addressed in accordance with the Agreement. The United States will provide Palau with $40,000,000 in grants for infrastructure projects over fiscal years 2014 to 2016. Additionally, the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 will be extended until 2024, and there will be a passport requirement under the Compact of Free Association. Nonimmigrants in the United States and its territories can be admitted without certain passport requirements if they fall into specific categories, including citizens of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands who are now citizens of Palau, those who acquire Palau citizenship at birth, and naturalized citizens who have been residents for at least five years. Citizens of Palau, whether by birth or naturalization, who have been residents for at least five years, are permitted to accept employment in the United States. However, their right to establish habitual residence in a U.S. territory or possession may be subject to non-discriminatory limitations. This does not grant them the right to establish residence for naturalization or petition for benefits under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Citizens of Palau have the right to accept employment in the United States after residing for at least five years. However, they are not granted the right to establish residence for naturalization or petition for benefits under the Immigration and Nationality Act.
